marichrd,"2017-02-07T20:26:14.577Z","London Skyline","

I bought this set a few weeks back and decided to do a quick build last night so set about this Skyline
column3: d been waiting for it to go on general release since first hearing about it, as it was initially released only in the new flagship Store at Leicester Square.

column2: s a fun build with a couple of nice touches especially with Tower Bridge although I was a little disappointed with the lack of arms on the London Eye.

column1: Overall build time was approximately 1hr. Overall it'
column2: s a nice set but I felt a little overpriced for what it is.

column1:
,TRUE,4,3,3,3,3 Darkmagi","2017-04-09T11:34:09.65Z","I Built this city on a lego roll","

This London
During the build there are a number of trivia snippets in the instructions.
There are many pieces in the box the base plate is made of loads and could have been simplified to give
Unfortunately all the buildings are not to scale to each other and are a mere representation of what the building sort of looks like.
Some of the very notable things that the
London eye has 16 pods half that of the real one. There are no stay wires to the centre. The eye does not move.
Tower Bridge the arches over the road could have covered the road.
Houses of Parliament the main feature is St Stephens Tower (AKA Big Ben) The clock only has one face whereas it should have 4.

column2: I loved the little tiny legoman&nbsp
column3: Nelson for the top. The Bronze Lions were a letdown as they were not the right part selected to depict a lion. There could have easily been an additional two fountains and/or the 4 plinths (where the statues are) The National Gallery in the background was well done.&nbsp

column5: ,sans-serif"">This set was in the second wave of Skyline sets within the Architecture theme, presenting a selection of iconic London-based buildings, rather than a single structure as had been the focus previously.

,sans-serif"">The box is the usual high-quality Architecture affair, with the set picture contrasting nicely against the black background. The instructions are also in the premium bracket, including not only the (very leisurely paced) building instructions, but also&nbsp
column6: information about each of the featured structures, as well as interesting facts about certain features as you get to the relevant stage in the build.

column5: ,sans-serif"">The colour palette is dominated by parts in white and tan, with black plates and tiles and dark grey pieces rounding the set out. There are also a surprisingly large number of trans clear pieces &ndash
column6: 40 of the 1x2 tiles (the most of any piece in the set) and 23 1x2 plates. As could be expected from a set where large architectural details need to be replicated at miniature scale, a large proportion of the total piece count consists of small parts, with around two thirds of them the same size or smaller than a 2x2 plate.

column5: ,sans-serif"">Exclusive parts include the name tile and a printed 2x2 brick, one side of which features a printed clock face (of which more later). A white Technic suspension piece, four short flexi tubes in blue, and four long flexible tubes in white are all also unique in those colours.

,sans-serif"">The build is taken at a decidedly slow pace in the instructions, often with only one or two pieces placed per step. The necessary, but uninteresting, layering of plates to make the base gives way to placing to tiles and jumper plates - suddenly adding all 40 of the 1x2 trans-clear tile in one step is a bit of shock, but they form a pleasing geometric pattern, broken up by 1x2 trans-clear plates.

,sans-serif"">Tower Bridge is the first actual structure to be built, with a little SNOT build for the piers and a lesson in Lego geometry for the bascules which fit perfectly between them. Placing a headlight brick on its back to provide detail while also taking advantage of the two-plates height of the element in this configuration is interesting, and a corner cut out brick accommodates the additional space required by the &lsquo
column7: stud internally while maintaining the continuity of the outer wall.

column5: ,sans-serif"">The National Gallery is fairly straightforward, making use of bricks with studs on the side to mount grill tiles vertically for the fa&ccedil
column6: ade. Various rounded elements slide onto a bar to make up the dome and spire.

column5: ,sans-serif"">The London Eye rolls out a more Technic approach, with vertical supports made from suspension pieces anchored via friction pins, the offset alignment allowing them to meet at the top and connected by a bar. The actual wheel itself goes together fairly quickly and I did follow the tip in the Brickset review of using a 1x2 brick with a tile on the top as a spacer for the placement of the London Eye &lsquo
column7: along the tubing, which was much easier than using the guide in the instructions. The tubing is curved into a wheel and connected with a small technic connector pin at the top and angled brackets at the bottom. The whole structure&nbsp
column8: is fixed to the base in a simple yet clever technique which utilises the clutch power of a bar inserted into a Technic friction pin which in turn is connecting the two angled technic connecting elements which are themselves providing the connection points for the flexible tubes which make up the wheel!

column5: ,sans-serif"">The Houses of Parliament are bit of an anti-climax as they are just so much brick stacking, except the placement of four of the old &lsquo
column7: parts of the roof which are then twisted to form a representation of the gothic detailing on the real building. Nelson&rsquo
column8: s Column and a sailing boat finish off the build.

column5: ,sans-serif"">The final result does what it says on the tin &ndash
column6: bringing together some of the most iconic and recognisable buildings from the London skyline into a well presented and visually balanced set that looks great on display. All the structures feature enough detailing to clearly represent the familiar architectural details, from SNOT-mounted &lsquo
column8: plates for the gothic revival Tower Bridge, to the white and glass aesthetic of the London Eye. The 1x1 vertical clips to represent the lion statues around the base of Nelson&rsquo
column9: s Column are a bit of a stretch, but not much else could be done at the scale &ndash
column10: it does at least provide an approximation of the texture.

column8: the clock face just seems to stand out in a bad way. So much of the set and theme is about using Lego elements to represent architectural details at reduced scale that the more &lsquo
column10: printing here looks out of place. The whole set does feel a little small for the RRP, though this is common to many Architecture sets due to the number of small pieces required, and can be good value if it can be found on sale. The lack of any of the modern buildings that have sprung up over the past ten years or more is noticeable (Eye excepted), especially as some of them would have provided a more interesting building&nbsp
column11: challenge then the Houses of Parliament or the National Gallery.

column5: ,sans-serif"">Having said that, all the chosen structures are well arranged, eschewing scale and geographical accuracy for something that just feels right &ndash
column6: and from this perspective, the sets succeeds wonderfully. It&rsquo
column7: s a great display piece, breaking out of the linear approach taken by its predecessors&nbsp
column8: to properly show off the iconic buildings of in the capital city. Now some years have passed since this set was released, maybe a second London skyline is called for, showcasing buildings post Victorian Era like Canary Wharf, The Shard, Walkie Talkie, the DLR&hellip

column1:
,TRUE,4,4,3,1,2 ArkahmAsylym","2018-12-22T13:55:09.753Z","Nice build but details could be better","

I love London! So I thought I would get this model.
column4: The finer tourist details of the city are there in all representation.&nbsp
column5: The problem is, the detailing is not very good unless you are looking at it from a distance.&nbsp
column6: The Big Ben clock face is very plain as well as the actual Elizabeth Tower roof&nbsp
column8: lacking. I was expecting it to at least have ridges along the break where the tower point meets the tower proper but it does not.&nbsp
column9: It is just a smooth transition from clock face to roof point.&nbsp
column10: It does have detailing on the lower 3/4 which is nice.&nbsp
column11: I also liked the Lego accent on top of Nelson&#39
column13: s a Lego figure). The best detailed part&nbsp
column14: of this set, though, was on The National Gallery.&nbsp
column15: The columns in the building are represented with grate like pieces that snap onto ridge imprinted blocks.&nbsp
column16: It was quite a clever illusion to the eye that looks very realistic as a building with columns.&nbsp
column17: The cleverest overall item was the London&nbsp
column19: The wheel was made up of two flexible&nbsp
column20: plastic rods that were held together by a Lego piece in a ring. These rings then had the &quot
column26: then attaches to the BASE. There are no support structures&nbsp
column28: wheel, again using an illusion to the eye that the rings are supported from the middle.&nbsp
column29: The trickiest part of building the Eye was lining up the car&nbsp
column31: They help you a lot with a real scale picture in the instructions to line the cars up on the rods.&nbsp
column32: My nick-pickiest part was the Tower Bridge.&nbsp
column33: This is my favorite London Landmark and when I first&nbsp
column34: saw it put together it did not meet my expectations.&nbsp
column35: Like Big Ben, I was expecting more detailing in the towers and walkways.&nbsp
column36: Once I had it together though, it grew on me and I found it ...&nbsp
column38: The support wires are made of flexible rubber compressed between base and tower.&nbsp
column39: That was really clever to get the sag in the cabling.

column1: With all this said, the set is worthy of your collection.
column2: It can be used as a shelf piece, like I&#39
column5: The model does not look bad from a few feet away.&nbsp
column6: The use of illusions to trick the eye is good enough to trick the keenest of eyes. Someone could only know the details if they get close, or they are a London Architecture aficionado.&nbsp
column7: I really doubt anyone would even notice the imperfections.
